description: About ________% of people working in the United States belong to unions.
explanation:
B) About 14 million U.S. workers belong to unionsâ€”around 11% of the total
number of men and women working in this country.

description: Costco is primarily known as "the anti-Walmart" because the firm ________.
explanation:
A) Some people call Costco "The Anti-Walmart," partly because of how Costco
treats its workers and unions. When California grocery store workers picketed several chains a
few years ago, "Costco Wholesale Corp. avoided the fray, quietly renegotiating a separate
contract with its union employees there." In contrast, Walmart is famously anti-union.

description:
Which of the following best explains a major reason why union membership in the United
States has fallen in the last 50 years?

options.A: Legislation provides workers with protections that were once exclusive to unions.
options.B: Union members earn less on average compared to non-union members.
options.C: Union membership is too expensive for most blue-collar workers.
options.D: Foreign-owned manufacturers will not hire union members.

description: Which of the following is most likely a false statement about union membership?

options.A: Union members work in both blue-collar and white-collar industries.
options.B: Insurance plan benefits are better for union workers than for nonunion workers.
options.C: Union workers receive more holidays and unpaid leave than nonunion workers do.
options.D: Employers prefer nonunion workers, so they pay them higher wages than union members.

explanation:
D) Recent median weekly wage for union workers was $917, while that for
nonunion workers was $717. Union workers also generally receive significantly more holidays,
sick leave, unpaid leave, insurance plan benefits, long-term disability benefits, and various other
benefits than nonunion workers do. Union membership is not exclusive to blue-collar workers.

description: Which of the following best describes the closed shop form of union security?

options.A: A company can hire nonunion people if they agree to join the union.
options.B: Union members receive higher wages than nonunion employees.
options.C: Union members receive preferential treatment in hiring.
options.D: A company can hire only union members.

explanation:
D) Under the closed shop form of union security, the company can hire only
current union members. Congress outlawed closed shops in interstate commerce in 1947, but
they still exist in some states for particular industries (such as printing). They account for fewer
than 5% of union contracts.

description: The ________ form of union security means that the company can hire only union members.
explanation:
A) Under the closed shop form of union security, the company can hire only
current union members. Congress outlawed closed shops in interstate commerce in 1947, but
they still exist in some states for particular industries.

description: Which type of union security was outlawed by Congress?
explanation:
B) Under the closed shop form of union security, the company can hire only
current union members. Congress outlawed closed shops in interstate commerce in 1947, but
they still exist in some states for particular industries.

description: Which type of union security accounts for almost three-fourths of union contracts?
explanation: C) The union shop accounts for about 73% of union contracts.

description:
The ________ form of union security means that the company can hire nonunion people, but
those people must join the union within a prescribed period of time and pay dues.
explanation:
B) With the union shop, the company can hire nonunion people, but they must join
the union after a prescribed period and pay dues.

description:
Which form of union security requires employees who do not belong to the union to pay
union dues on the assumption that the union's efforts benefit all workers?
explanation:
B) With the agency shop, employees who do not belong to the union still must pay
the union an amount equal to union dues on the assumption that the union's efforts benefit all the
workers.

description: Which of the following best defines the preferential shop form of union security?

options.A: A company can hire nonunion people, but they must then join the union.
options.B: Union members must maintain membership for the contract period.
options.C: Employees who do not belong to the union must still pay dues.
options.D: A company gives hiring advantages to union members.

explanation: D) With preferential shop, union members receive preference in hiring.

description:
With the maintenance of membership arrangement of union security, how long must union
members employed by a firm maintain union membership?
explanation:
C) With the maintenance of membership arrangement, employees do not have to
belong to the union. However, union members employed by the firm must maintain membership
in the union for the contract period.

description:
The term ________ describes statutory or constitutional provisions banning the requirement
of union membership as a condition of employment.
explanation:
B) Right to work is a term used to describe state statutory or constitutional
provisions banning the requirement of union membership as a condition of employment. Right to
work laws don't outlaw unions, but they do outlaw any form of union security.

description: Right to work laws inhibit union formation by ________.

options.A: banning any form of union security
options.C: leaving the question of union affiliation up to each company
options.D: leaving the question of union security up to each company

explanation:
A) Right-to-work laws don't outlaw unions. They do outlaw (within those states)
any form of union security. Right to work is a term used to describe state statutory or
constitutional provisions banning the requirement of union membership as a condition of
employment.

description: In which human resource activity does a typical labor agreement NOT give the union a role?
explanation:
D) The typical labor agreement also gives the union a role in other human resource
activities, including recruiting, selecting, compensating, promoting, training, and discharging
employees. Unions typically play no role in performance appraisals.

description: Which of the following best describes the AFL-CIO?

options.A: voluntary federation of national and international labor unions
options.B: local union for automobile workers in Detroit, Michigan
options.C: federation of firms that fight unionization in their plants
options.D: regional branch of the National Labor Relations Board

explanation:
A) The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations
(AFL-CIO) is a voluntary federation of about 57 national and international labor unions in the
United States.

description: Which of the following best describes a "yellow dog" contract?

options.A: As a condition of employment, an employee agrees not to picket.
options.B: Employers agree to give union members preference in hiring.
options.C: As a condition of employment, an employee agrees to not join a union.
options.D: Employers agree to abide by the guidelines of the local labor unions.

explanation:
C) "Yellow dog" contracts, whereby management could require nonunion
membership as a condition for employment, were widely enforced until about 1930.

description:
Prior to 1930, employers attempted to limit the influence of unions using all of the following
methods EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
D) Until about 1930, there were no special labor laws. Employers were not
required to engage in collective bargaining with employees and were virtually unrestrained in
their behavior toward unions; the use of spies and firing of union agitators were widespread.
"Yellow dog" contracts were widely enforced.

description:
Which of the following guaranteed each employee the right to bargain collectively without
interference, restraint, or coercion?
explanation:
B) The Norris-LaGuardia Act of 1932 guaranteed to each employee the right to
bargain collectively "free from interference, restraint, or coercion." The National Labor Relations
Act added on to Norris-LaGuardia by banning certain unfair labor practices.

description:
Which of the following bans five unfair labor practices and provides for majority rule and
secret ballot elections?
explanation:
D) Congress passed the National Labor Relations (or Wagner) Act to add teeth to
Norris-LaGuardia. It did this by banning certain unfair labor practices and by providing for
secret-ballot elections and majority rule for determining whether a firm's employees would
unionize.

description: Which of the following was established by the Wagner Act?
explanation:
B) The Wagner Act created the National Labor Relations Board to enforce the
provisions of the act.

description: Which of the following was passed in 1935 to amend the Norris -LaGuardia Act?
explanation:
C) In 1935, Congress passed the National Labor Relations (or Wagner) Act to add
teeth to Norris-LaGuardia. It did this by (1) banning certain unfair labor practices, (2) providing
for secret-ballot elections and majority rule for determining whether a firm's employees would
unionize, and (3) creating the National Labor Relations Board.

description: Which of the following best describes a main purpose of the Wagner Act?

options.A:
guaranteeing each employee the right to bargain collectively free from interference and
coercion
options.B: banning unions from preventing employees from exercising their guaranteed bargaining rights
options.C: allowing secret-ballot elections for determining whether a firm's employees would unionize
options.D: making it illegal for a union to refuse to bargain in good faith with the employer

explanation:
C) In 1935, Congress passed the National Labor Relations (or Wagner) Act to add
teeth to Norris-LaGuardia. It did this by (1) banning certain unfair labor practices, (2) providing
for secret-ballot elections and majority rule for determining whether a firm's employees would
unionize, and (3) creating the National Labor Relations Board.

description: The National Labor Relations Board was primarily established for the purpose of ________.

options.B: negotiating contracts on behalf of local unions
options.D: overseeing the establishment of local unions

explanation:
C) The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) was created by the Wagner Act to
investigate unfair labor practice charges and to provide for secret-ballot elections and majority
rule in determining whether or not a firm's employees want a union.

description: Which of the following was NOT designated an unfair labor practice by the Wagner Act?
explanation:
C) Yellow-dog contracts were deemed unenforceable under the Norris-LaGuardia
Act. The Wagner Act deemed it unfair to bribe employees, use company spy systems, move a
business to avoid unionization, and black-list union sympathizers.

description: Which of the following is the most likely reason for the passage of the Taft-Hartley Act?
explanation:
D) Largely because of a series of massive postwar strikes, public policy began to
shift against what many viewed as union excesses. Passage of the Taft-Hartley Act occurred to
limit the power of unions.

description:
The Taft-Hartley Act amended the Wagner Act in all of the following ways EXCEPT by
________.

options.C: limiting the power of the National Labor Review Board
options.D: allowing the U.S. President to bar national emergency strikes

explanation:
C) The Taft-Hartley Act did not alter the power of the NLRB. The law prohibited
unfair labor practices, enumerated the rights of employers and employees, and allowed the
President to bar national emergency strikes on a temporary basis.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to an unfair labor practice in which a union requires an
employer to pay an employee for services not performed?
explanation:
D) It is an unfair labor practice for a union to engage in featherbedding.
Featherbedding involves requiring an employer to pay an employee for services not performed.

description: The Taft-Hartley Act prohibits all of the following union labor practices EXCEPT ________.

options.A: forcing an employer to fire a worker for failing to attend union meetings
options.B: refusing to bargain in good faith with an employer about wages and hours
options.C: restraining or coercing employees from exercising their guaranteed bargaining rights
options.D: demanding an employer fire a worker who fails to pay union dues in a closed shop

explanation:
D) Where a closed or union shop prevails (and union membership is therefore a
prerequisite to employment), the union may demand the discharge of someone who fails to pay
his or her initiation fees and dues. The other actions are considered unfair union labor practices
under the Taft-Hartley Act.

description:
You are a manager at a manufacturing facility, and you tell your subordinates that unions are
dangerous to the economy. Which law protects your right to express these views?
explanation:
B) The Taft-Hartley Act explicitly gave employers certain rights, such as
expressing their views concerning union organization.

description:
Which law sought to protect union members from possible wrongdoing on the part of their
unions?
explanation:
D) The Landrum-Griffin Act of 1959 was intended to protect union members from
possible wrongdoing on the part of their unions.

description:
According to the Landrum-Griffin Act, national and international unions must elect officers
at least once every ________ years.
explanation:
D) The Landrum-Griffin Act laid out rules regarding union elections. For example,
national and international unions must elect officers at least once every five years, using some
type of secret-ballot mechanism.

description: What is the first step in the union drive process?
explanation:
B) During the initial contact stage, the union determines the employees' interest in
organizing and establishes an organizing committee. The initiative for the first contact between
the employees and the union may come from the employees, from a union already representing
other employees of the firm, or from a union representing workers elsewhere. Obtaining
authorization cards, holding hearings, and campaigning for election votes occur later in the
process.

description:
Which of the following is a union organizing tactic by which union members are placed on
nonunion job sites?
explanation:
B) The National Labor Relations Board defines union salting as "placing of union
members on nonunion job sites for the purpose of organizing."

description:
What percentage of eligible employees in a bargaining unit must sign authorization cards in
order for the union to petition the NLRB for an election?
explanation:
B) Thirty percent of the eligible employees in an appropriate bargaining unit must
sign before the union can petition the NLRB for an election.

description: Union authorization cards serve all of the following functions EXCEPT ________.

options.A: subjecting the employee to union rules
options.B: stating that the employee has applied for membership
options.C: enabling employers to modify employment conditions
options.D: designating the union as a bargaining representative

explanation:
C) Union authorization cards authorize the union to seek a representation election
and designate the union as a bargaining representative. They state that the employee has applied
to join the union and is subject to union rules. The cards do not permit employers to modify
employment conditions.

description:
Hyper-Tech Enterprises manufactures mechanical parts used in air conditioning and heating
units. The company employs over 300 workers at its Alabama facility. None of the Hyper-Tech
employees belong to a union; however, management believes that unionization is in the near
future. A representative of a local union has recently visited Hyper-Tech in an attempt to solicit
members and have them sign authorization cards. Enough eligible employees have signed
authorization cards to petition the NLRB for an election. Hyper-Tech's top executives are
considering fighting the unionization efforts.
Which of the following questions is LEAST relevant to the decision by Hyper-Tech to fight
unionization efforts?

options.A: How many Hyper-Tech employees were hired within the last year?
options.B: What percentage of Hyper-Tech employees signed authorization cards?
options.C: What is the opinion of Hyper-Tech's shareholders and creditors regarding unionization?
options.D:
What are the laws regarding what Hyper-Tech managers can and cannot do during a
campaign?

explanation:
A) The number of newly hired employees is least relevant to the firm's decision to
fight unionization. The number of employees who have signed authorization cards, the opinion
of stakeholders, and labor laws are more relevant to the decision.

description:
Hyper-Tech Enterprises manufactures mechanical parts used in air conditioning and heating
units. The company employs over 300 workers at its Alabama facility. None of the Hyper-Tech
employees belong to a union; however, management believes that unionization is in the near
future. A representative of a local union has recently visited Hyper-Tech in an attempt to solicit
members and have them sign authorization cards. Enough eligible employees have signed
authorization cards to petition the NLRB for an election. Hyper-Tech's top executives are
considering fighting the unionization efforts.
Which of the following, if true, best supports the argument that Hyper-Tech should contest the
union's right to an election?

options.A:
Managers believe that they may have inadvertently hired union salts, who most likely
instigated the unionization movement at Hyper-Tech.
options.B:
The process outlined at Hyper-Tech for filing employee grievances differs from the grievance
procedures at other firms in the same industry.
options.C:
Hyper-Tech management believes that if employees are provided with additional information
from the firm that they will revoke their authorization cards.
options.D:
Hyper-Tech managers will soon be conducting annual employee performance appraisals and
determining what salary adjustments to make.

explanation:
C) If Hyper-Tech wants to contest the union's right, it can insist on a hearing to
determine those issues. An employer's decision about whether to insist on a hearing is a strategic
one. Management bases it on the facts of each case and on whether it feels it needs more time to
try to persuade employees not to elect a union.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to the group of employees the union will be authorized
to represent?
explanation:
A) The bargaining unit is the group of employees that the union will be authorized
to represent and bargain for collectively. If the entire organization is the bargaining unit, the
union will represent all nonsupervisory, nonmanagerial, and nonconfidential employees, even
though the union may be oriented mostly toward blue-collar workers.

description: The union becomes the employees' representative if it receives ________.

options.A: a majority of the votes cast by the bargaining unit
options.B: signed authorization cards from 30% of employees
options.D: a majority of the votes cast

explanation:
D) The union becomes the employees' representative if it wins the election, and
winning means getting a majority of the votes cast, not a majority of the total workers in the
bargaining unit.

description:
Which of the following situations would most likely improve a union's chances of winning a
certification election at Apex Enterprises?

options.A: geographic area with low percentage of union workers
options.B: high unemployment in the geographic area
options.C: a large portion of workers voting

explanation:
D) Unions have a higher probability of success in geographic areas with a higher
percentage of union workers. High unemployment seems to lead to poorer results for the union.
The larger the bargaining unit, the smaller the probability of union victory. The more workers
vote, the less likely a union victory.

description:
All of the following increase the likelihood that an employer will lose an NLRB election
EXCEPT ________.

options.A: focusing primarily on wage and benefits issues
options.B: appointing a committee to manage the campaign
options.C: distributing employee need and attitude surveys
options.D: delegating personnel relations issues to plant managers

explanation:
C) Employers tend to lose elections when they focus too much on wages and
benefits, appoint uninformed committees to manage campaigns, and delegate union issues.
Employers are more likely to win if they address the attitudes and concerns of all workers by
sending out surveys and responding to their needs.

description:
Hyper-Tech Enterprises manufactures mechanical parts used in air conditioning and heating
units. The company employs over 300 workers at its Alabama facility. None of the Hyper-Tech
employees belong to a union; however, management believes that unionization is in the near
future. A representative of a local union has recently visited Hyper-Tech in an attempt to solicit
members and have them sign authorization cards. Enough eligible employees have signed
authorization cards to petition the NLRB for an election. Hyper-Tech's top executives are
considering fighting the unionization efforts.
Which of the following, if true, best supports the suggestion that Hyper-Tech will lose an NLRB
election?

options.A: Hyper-Tech recently distributed employee surveys that indicated overall job satisfaction.
options.B: Hyper-Tech executives have decided that a committee should manage the campaign.
options.C: Hyper-Tech managers have been told to share their opinions about unions with subordinates.
options.D: Hyper-Tech managers have been told to avoid making promises to their subordinates.

explanation:
B) Forming a committee to manage a campaign is usually detrimental to firms
because of the slow nature of committees in making decisions. Experts suggest giving full
responsibility to a single, decisive executive. Sharing opinions about unions is acceptable.

description:
Hyper-Tech Enterprises manufactures mechanical parts used in air conditioning and heating
units. The company employs over 300 workers at its Alabama facility. None of the Hyper-Tech
employees belong to a union; however, management believes that unionization is in the near
future. A representative of a local union has recently visited Hyper-Tech in an attempt to solicit
members and have them sign authorization cards. Enough eligible employees have signed
authorization cards to petition the NLRB for an election. Hyper-Tech's top executives are
considering fighting the unionization efforts.
Which of the following, if true, supports the argument by the NLRB that Hyper-Tech has
conducted unfair labor practices?

options.A:
Hyper-Tech managers prohibited union representatives from soliciting employees who were
on duty.
options.B:
Hyper-Tech managers intervened when pro-union employees solicited other employees while
both were on duty.
options.C:
Hyper-Tech managers barred nonemployee union representatives from entering the firm's
building.
options.D: Hyper-Tech managers prohibited distribution of union literature in the company cafeteria.

explanation:
D) The NLRB has ruled that the act of prohibiting distribution of the literature is
an unfair labor practice. Most employers can bar nonemployees from the building's interiors and
work areas as a right of private property owners.

description: ________ is the process of legally terminating a union's right to represent employees.
explanation:
C) The same law that grants employees the right to unionize also gives them a way
to terminate legally their union's right to represent them. The process is called decertification.

description:
When representatives of Ford's management and the autoworkers' union meet to negotiate a
labor agreement, which of the following is most likely occurring?
explanation:
D) Collective bargaining is the process through which representatives of
management and the union meet to negotiate a labor agreement.

description: Which of the following is a characteristic of good faith bargaining?
explanation:
B) Good faith bargaining is characterized by both parties making every reasonable
effort to arrive at an agreement. Proposals are matched with counterproposals in good faith
bargaining. Overlooking bargaining items, bypassing union representatives, and imposing
unreasonable conditions are actions indicating that bargaining is not in good faith.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to items in collective bargaining over which bargaining
is neither illegal nor mandatory?
All of the following are examples of mandatory bargaining items EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
C) Mandatory bargaining items are items in collective bargaining that a party must
bargain over if they are introduced by the other party, such as wages, hours, rest periods, layoffs,
transfers, benefits, drug testing and severance pay. Voluntary bargaining items, which are neither
mandatory nor illegal, such as indemnity bonds, become a part of negotiations only through the
joint agreement of both management and union.

description: All of the following are examples of permissible bargaining items EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
B) Mandatory bargaining items are items in collective bargaining that a party must
bargain over if they are introduced by the other party, such as severance pay. Permissible
bargaining items become a part of negotiations only through the joint agreement of both
management and union. Cafeteria prices, the scope of the bargaining unit, and pension benefits
are permissible bargaining items.

description: Which of the following is an illegal bargaining item?
explanation:
B) Illegal bargaining items are items in collective bargaining that are forbidden by
law, such as discriminatory treatment. Bargaining team membership, contract continuances, and
strikebreaker employment are permissible items.

description:
Managers from Ford and representatives from United Auto Workers are in the first stage of
collective bargaining over benefits and wages. Which of the following is most likely occurring?

options.A: Subcommittees are forming to create alternatives.
options.B: Each side is trading some of its demands.
options.C: Each side is checking terms with superiors.
options.D: Each side is presenting its demands.

explanation:
D) In the first stage of bargaining, each side presents its demands. At this stage,
both parties are usually quite far apart on some issues.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to a collective bargaining situation that occurs when the
parties are not able to move further toward settlement?
explanation:
A) In collective bargaining, an impasse occurs when the parties are not able to
move further toward settlement. An impasse usually occurs because one party is demanding
more than the other will offer.

description:
Negotiators use all of the following types of third-party interventions to overcome an
impasse EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
D) Negotiators use three types of third-party interventions to overcome an
impasse: mediation, fact finding, and arbitration. Picketing is not a third-party intervention
method.

description:
Which third-party intervention uses a neutral third party to assist the principals in reaching
agreement?
explanation:
B) With mediation, a neutral third party tries to assist the principals in reaching
agreement.
The mediator usually holds meetings with each party to determine where each stands regarding
its position and then uses this information to find common ground for further bargaining.

description:
Which intervention method listed below is the most definitive of all third-party
interventions?
explanation:
C) Binding arbitration is the most definitive type of third-party intervention,
because the arbitrator often has the power to determine and dictate the settlement terms. Unlike
mediation and fact finding, arbitration can guarantee a solution to an impasse.

description: Fact finding seeks to end an impasse by ________.

options.A: assisting the principals in reaching an agreement
options.B: studying the issues and making a public recommendation
options.C: interpreting and analyzing existing contract terms
options.D: communicating assessments of the likelihood of a strike

explanation:
B) A fact finder is a neutral party who studies the issues in a dispute and makes a
public recommendation for a reasonable settlement.

description:
The National Air Traffic Controllers Association and the Federal Aviation Administration
have reached an impasse during collective bargaining. Which of the following will most likely
be used to reach a settlement?
explanation:
A) Presidential emergency fact-finding boards have successfully resolved impasses
in certain critical transportation disputes. Mediation and arbitration are less likely to be used
during this national emergency strike.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to a strike that takes place when one union strikes in
support of another union?
explanation:
D) A sympathy strike occurs when one union strikes in support of the strike of
another union.

description:
A strike that results from a failure to agree on the terms of a contract, such as wages and
benefits, is known as a(n) ________ strike.
explanation:
B) An economic strike results from a failure to agree on the terms of a contract.
Unions call unfair labor practice strikes to protest illegal conduct by the employer. A wildcat
strike is an unauthorized strike occurring during the term of a contract.

description:
Employers dealing with an unfair labor practice strike can use all of the following responses
EXCEPT ________.

options.A: shutting down the affected area until the strike ends
options.B: continuing operations with supervisors filling in

explanation:
D) Employers cannot permanently replace strikers who are protesting unfair labor
practices. Shutting down affected areas, having managers fill in, and hiring temporary workers
are options in such a situation.

description:
Union tactics designed to impede or disrupt production by encouraging employees to slow
the pace of work, refuse to work overtime, and participate in sick-outs are called ________.
explanation:
A) Inside games are union efforts to convince employees to impede or to disrupt
production, such as by slowing the work pace, refusing to work overtime. Inside games are
basically strikes in which the company continues to pay the employees.

description:
Manning Enterprises is experiencing an impasse between management and labor. As a result,
the union has made an organized effort to pressure Manning by picketing the homes of corporate
directors and boycotting the firm's bank. Which of the following terms best describes the actions
of Manning's union members?
explanation:
C) Management and labor each have other weapons to break an impasse and
achieve their aims. The union, for example, may resort to a corporate campaign. A corporate
campaign is an organized effort by the union that exerts pressure on the employer by pressuring
the company's other unions, shareholders, corporate directors, customers, creditors, and
government agencies.

description:
Smithson management has refused to provide union workers with work shifts as a result of
reaching an impasse during collective bargaining. Which of the following best describes
Smithson's actions?
explanation:
A) Employers can try to break an impasse with lockouts. A lockout is a refusal by
the employer to provide opportunities to work. It (sometimes literally) locks out employees and
prohibits them from doing their jobs (and being paid).

description: What is the primary purpose of picketing?

options.A: informing the public about a labor dispute
options.B: increasing the likelihood of a lockout

explanation:
A) Picketing is one of the first activities to occur during a strike. The purpose is to
inform the public about the labor dispute.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to the formal process for addressing any factor
involving wages, hours, or conditions of employment that is used as a complaint against the
employer?
explanation:
C) The grievance procedure provides an orderly system whereby both employer
and union determine whether some action violated the contract. The grievance process allows
both parties to interpret and give meaning to various clauses, and transforms the contract into a
"living organism."

description:
Jeff is a manager at a paper mill. He has received a grievance from a group of employees
who are union members. The grievance claims that a plant rule barring employees from eating
during unscheduled breaks is arbitrary and unfair. What should Jeff most likely do?

options.A: Discuss the case privately with the union steward.
options.B: Agree to make informal changes to the rules.

explanation:
C) It is appropriate for Jeff to review the employees' personnel files. However,
discussing the issue privately with the union steward, making informal rule changes, and making
special arrangements are considered inappropriate methods for handling grievances.

description:
All of the following most likely explain the decline in union membership EXCEPT
________.
explanation:
A) Increased global competition and new technologies like the Internet and just-in-
time production systems forced employers to reduce inefficiencies and cut costs. Changes in
salaries and wages are less likely to be a cause.

description: If passed, the Employee Free Choice Act would ________.

options.A: ban union membership for federal employees
options.B: allow mass union e-mails at the workplace
options.C: allow the formation of global unions

explanation:
D) Unions are pushing Congress to pass the Employee Free Choice Act. This
would make it more difficult for employers to inhibit workers from organizing. Instead of secret-
ballot elections, the act would institute a "card check" system. Here, the union would win
recognition when a majority of workers signed authorization cards saying they want the union.

description:
Vaughn Manufacturing develops and manufactures microphone components. Over the last
few years, the firm has made numerous HR changes with the goal of becoming a high-
performance work system. Vaughn employees work in self-directed teams, participate in regular
training programs, and receive frequent performance appraisals. Vaughn executives want to
make sure that the firm's new methods are not perceived as sham unions. Which of the following
would most likely help Vaughn accomplish this goal?

options.A: allowing employee teams to bargain over wages

explanation:
D) Involving workers in the formation of participation programs will minimize the
appearance of sham unions. Firms should not allow teams to bargain, overly supervise
committee activities, or elect representatives.
